bibl.title: Letter from Lunsford D. Fricks to Henry Rose Carter, October 24, 1922

div1.p: Fricks hopes that Carter will be able to attend the Chattanooga meetings.

div1.head: Letter from Lunsford D. Fricks to Henry Rose Carter, October 24, 1922
div1.opener:
N. M. C.
Meeting
OFFICE OF
MALARIA INVESTIGATIONS
FIELD HEADQUARTERS
ROOM 17, COURTHOUSE
JG
TREASURY DEPARTMENT
UNITED STATES
PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
MEMPHIS, TENN.
October 24, 1922
Asst. Surgeon-General H. R. Carter,
U. S: Public Health Service,
2121 California Street, N.W.,
Washington, D. C.
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
I was delighted to learn from your letter of
October 22nd that there is a possibility of your being
with us at Chattanooga. We are always glad to have you
with us and I know that your presence alone always serves
as a stimulus to us younger men who are trying to carry
on the fight in a manner worthy of the traditions of the
old guard.

You will recall that I tried to arrange for your
presence at our last meeting without expense to yourself.
This year, I suggested to Dr. Welch that he arrange a con-
ference which he had in mind relative to his impounded
water regulations so that it would enable you to attend
the Chattanooga meetings without having to pay your rail-
road fare. I have not yet learned whether this has been
done but hope for the best.

I sincerely hope that you will find it possible
to be with us and am enclosing an identification certificate,
furnished me for distribution by Mr. Loranz, which you are
entitled to use in case you find it possible to be with us.

Several months ago, you wrote me that you were
sending me a copy of “Practice of Medicine in the Tropics”,
which you desired me to send on to Dr. Carter in Birmingham
when I had finished with it. The book came later and I have
read the chapters on malaria. Do you still wish me to send
it to your son?
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, L. D. Fricks, Surgeon,
Medical Officer in Charge.
